string-array.name: tips_quotes
string-array.item: You don’t have to use alcohol or other drugs to have fun
Don’t get into a car with a driver who has been drinking
Don’t leave drinks unattended
Don’t accept drinks from strangers.
Know where you’re going and how you’re getting there
Its a good idea to plan how you will get home before you start drinking; also have a back-up plan
Keep yourself hydrated when drinking
Know your limits learn to say ‘No’
Do not succumb to peer pressure.
Don’t drink on an empty stomach.
The general rule of thumb is that 2 "Standard Drinks" in the first hour will raise your BAC to 0.05%, and one "Standard Drink" per hour thereafter will maintain that level
Don’t make any sexual choices when you’ve been drinking.
Avoid drinking games

string-array.name: alcohol_stages
string-array.item: Sub-Clinical: Behavior basically normal by ordinary observation

Euphoria: Mild euphoria, sociability, talkativeness, increased self-confidence; decreased inhibitions. Diminution of attention, judgment and control. Beginning of sensory-motor impairment. Loss of efficiency in finer performance tests

Excitement: Emotional instability; loss of critical judgment. Impairment of perception, memory and comprehension. Decreased sensory response; increased reaction time. Reduced visual acuity; peripheral vision and glare recovery. Loss of sensory-motor coordination; impaired balance. Drowsiness.

Confusion: Disorientation, mental confusion; dizziness. Exaggerated emotional states. Disturbances of vision and of perception of color, form, motion and dimensions. Increased pain threshold. Increased loss of muscular coordination; staggering gait; slurred speech. Apathy, lethargy.

Stupor: General inertia; approaching loss of motor functions. Markedly decreased response to stimuli. High decrease in muscular coordination; inability to stand or walk. Vomiting; incontinence. Impaired consciousness; sleep or stupor.
Coma: Complete unconsciousness. Depressed or abolished reflexes. Subnormal body temperature. Incontinence. Impairment of circulation and respiration. Possible death.
Death: Result from respiratory arrest
